Brian Green's book "The Fabric of the Universe" explains that movement thruogh time and movement through space are relative. All motion is a combination of movement through space AND time, and that total equals the speed of light. (Einetein's special relativity) 
 
 The two extream examples would be a "stationary" object, where 100 % of it's movement would be through time; and light, moving at C, where 100% of it's movement would be through space. 
 
 So, is it correct to say that from the perspective of light, light has no element of time?
 
 If light has no element of time, is it infinite? We know it has a beginning, just turn on a light bulb, but will that same light if unobstructed travel to infinity?
